low: Low humidity causes moisture loss from sensors, leading to inaccurate readings over time
Dry air conditions can raise sensor temperatures unnecessarily, affecting device performance
Humidity too low may cause static electricity buildup, risking sensor circuit damage
Low moisture levels can cause corrosion issues on electronic components and connectors
Dry conditions reduce sensor sensitivity, leading to less accurate water quality monitoring
Humidity drops affect calibration stability, requiring more frequent sensor maintenance
Low humidity causes evaporation from sensor ports, potentially damaging internal electronics
Dry air conditions can cause thermal stress on device components, shortening lifespan
Humidity too low increases risk of dust and contaminant entry into sensitive devices
Low moisture levels can affect battery performance in humidity-dependent power systems
high: High humidity promotes mold and fungal growth around sensors, damaging device integrity
Excessive moisture can cause condensation on circuit boards, risking short circuits
Humidity too high may lead to water ingress through seals, corroding internal components
High moisture levels can damage electronic sensors, affecting measurement accuracy
Excessive humidity promotes bacterial growth that can contaminate sensor surfaces
High humidity causes corrosion on metal connectors and electrical contacts
Moisture buildup can lead to device malfunction and require premature replacement
High humidity affects calibration by changing reference measurements consistently
Excess moisture can cause fogging on optical sensors, disrupting water quality readings
Humidity levels too high risk device failure in critical aquaculture monitoring situations
